description.narrative: Farm power in Sub-Saharan countries is declining due to the collapse of most tractor-hire schemes, decreasing numbers of draught animals, and decreasing human labour. To sustainably intensify agriculture in this region, increased power through mechanisation and energy-saving practices such as conservation agriculture will be needed. This project is looking at the potential for small-scale machines to improve farming practices in Ethiopia, Kenya, Tanzania and Zimbabwe, including planting, harvesting, milling and transport. Multidisciplinary research activities will include participatory on-farm evaluations, business model development and institution and policy analysis. The main outputs will be the identification of appropriate tractors and business models to deliver these to smallholder farmers. The project will also identify opportunities to create new markets for equipment and services, and inform the development of related policies and networks for wide delivery.
